trans-unit.source: Represents a Windows progress bar control contained in a <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.StatusStrip"></xref>.
<xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar> is the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ProgressBar> optimized for hosting in a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStrip>.

A subset of the hosted control's properties and events are exposed at the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar> level, but the underlying <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ProgressBar> control is fully accessible through the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.ProgressBar%2A> property.
A <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar> control visually indicates the progress of a lengthy operation.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar> control displays a bar that fills in from left to right with the system highlight color as an operation progresses.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar> control can only be oriented horizontally.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar> control is typically used when an application performs tasks such as copying files or printing documents.
Users of an application might consider an application unresponsive if there is no visual cue.
Use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar> to notify the user that the application is performing a lengthy task and that the application is still responding.

The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Maximum%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Minimum%2A> properties define the range of values to represent the progress of a task.

The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Minimum%2A> property is typically set to a value of zero, and the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Maximum%2A> property is typically set to a value indicating the completion of a task.

For example, to display the progress properly when copying a group of files, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Maximum%2A> property could be set to the total number of files to be copied.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Value%2A> property represents the progress that the application has made toward completing the operation.

Because the bar displayed in the control is a collection of blocks, the value displayed by the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar> only approximates the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Value%2A> property's current value.
Based on the size of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar>, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Value%2A> property determines when to display the next block.

There are a number of ways to modify the value displayed by the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar> other than changing the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Value%2A> property directly.

You can use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Step%2A> property to specify a specific value to increment the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Value%2A> property by, and then call the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.PerformStep%2A> method to increment the value.

To vary the increment value, you can use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Increment%2A> method and specify a value by which to increment the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Value%2A> property.
<xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar> replaces the older <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ProgressBar> control, which is nevertheless retained for backward compatibility.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar"></xref> class.

By default, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Minimum%2A> property is set to 0, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Maximum%2A> property is set to 100, and the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Step%2A> property is set to 10.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar"></xref> class with specified name.
The name of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar"></xref>.
This property is not relevant to this class.
This property is not relevant to this class.
The background image displayed in the control.
This property is not relevant to this class.
This property is not relevant to this class.
An <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ImageLayout"></xref> value.
Gets the spacing between the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar"></xref> and adjacent items.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Padding"></xref> value representing the spacing.
Gets the height and width of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar"></xref> in pixels.
A <xref href="System.Drawing.Point.#ctor(System.Drawing.Size)"></xref> value representing the height and width.
Advances the current position of the progress bar by the specified amount.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Increment%2A> method enables you to increment the value of the progress bar by a specific amount.

This method of incrementing the progress bar is similar to using the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Step%2A> property with the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.PerformStep%2A> method.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Value%2A> property specifies the current position of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar>.

If, after calling the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Increment%2A> method, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Value%2A> property is greater than the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Maximum%2A> property, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Value%2A> property remains at the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Maximum%2A> property.

If, after calling the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Increment%2A> method with a negative value specified in the `value` parameter, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Value%2A> property is less than the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Minimum%2A> property, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Value%2A> property remains at the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Minimum%2A> property.
The amount by which to increment the progress bar's current position.
This event is not relevant for this class.
This event is not relevant for this class.
This event is not relevant for this class.
This event is not relevant for this class.
This event is not relevant for this class.
This event is not relevant for this class.
This event is not relevant for this class.
This event is not relevant for this class.
Gets or sets a value representing the delay between each <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ProgressBarStyle.Marquee"></xref> display update, in milliseconds.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.MarqueeAnimationSpeed%2A> property gets or sets the delay of display update.
Therefore, as you decrease the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.MarqueeAnimationSpeed%2A> property, the speed of the animation increases.
An integer representing the delay, in milliseconds.
Gets or sets the upper bound of the range that is defined for this <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar"></xref>.
This property specifies the upper limit of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Value%2A> property.

When the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Maximum%2A> property is changed, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar> control is redrawn to reflect the new range of the control.

When the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Value%2A> property is equal to the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Maximum%2A> property, the progress bar is completely filled.

You can use this property to specify a value that the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Value%2A> property must be set to (by setting the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Value%2A> property or using the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Increment%2A> or <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.PerformStep%2A> methods) to indicate that an operation is complete.
For example, you can set the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Maximum%2A> property to the total number of files in a file copy operation.
Each time a file is copied, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Value%2A> property can be increased by one until the total number of files is copied.
At that point, the progress bar would be completely filled.
An integer representing the upper bound of the range.
The default is 100.
Gets or sets the lower bound of the range that is defined for this <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar"></xref>.
This property specifies the lower limit of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Value%2A> property.

When the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Minimum%2A> property is changed, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar> control is redrawn to reflect the new range of the control.

When the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Value%2A> property is equal to the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Minimum%2A> property, the progress bar is empty.

To change the value of the progress bar, use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Step%2A> property with the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.PerformStep%2A> method, use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Increment%2A> method, or set the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Value%2A> property directly.
An integer representing the lower bound of the range.
The default is 0.
Raises the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ProgressBar.RightToLeftLayoutChanged"></xref> event.
Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate.
For more information, see [Events](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/b6f65241-e0ad-4590-a99f-200ce741bb1f).
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.OnRightToLeftLayoutChanged%2A> method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate.
This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.
An <xref href="System.EventArgs"></xref> that contains the event data.
Subscribes events from the hosted control.
The control from which to subscribe events.
Unsubscribes events from the hosted control.
The control from which to unsubscribe events.
This event is not relevant for this class.
This event is not relevant for this class.
Advances the current position of the progress bar by the amount of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Step"></xref> property.

The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.PerformStep%2A> method increments the value of the progress bar by the amount specified by the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Step%2A> property.
You can use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Step%2A> property to specify the amount that each completed task in an operation changes the value of the progress bar.

For example, if you are copying a group of files, you might want to set the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Step%2A> property to 1 and the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Maximum%2A> property to the total number of files to copy.

When each file is copied, you can call the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.PerformStep%2A> method to increment the progress bar by the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Step%2A> property.

If you want to have more flexible control of the value of the progress bar, you can use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Increment%2A> method or set the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Value%2A> property directly.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Value%2A> property specifies the current position of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar>.

If, after calling the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.PerformStep%2A> method, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Value%2A> property is greater than the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Maximum%2A> property, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Value%2A> property remains at the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Maximum%2A> property.

If, after calling the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.PerformStep%2A> method with a negative value specified in the `value` parameter, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Value%2A> property is less than the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Minimum%2A> property, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Value%2A> property remains at the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Minimum%2A> property.
Gets the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ProgressBar"></xref>.
This is a strongly typed accessor for this <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar>.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ProgressBar"></xref> object associated with the control.

Gets or sets a value indicating whether the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar"></xref> layout is right-to-left or left-to-right when the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.RightToLeft"></xref> property is set to <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.RightToLeft.Yes"></xref>.
Use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.RightToLeftLayout%2A> property to control the layout of international applications in which the language is written from right to left.

When the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.RightToLeftLayout%2A> property is `true`, and the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.RightToLeft> property is set to <xref:System.Windows.Forms.RightToLeft.Yes>, mirroring will be enabled on the Windows form and control placement and text will be from right to left.

`true` to turn on mirroring and lay out control from right to left when the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.RightToLeft"></xref> property is set to <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.RightToLeft.Yes"></xref>; otherwise, `false`.
The default is `false`.
Occurs when the value of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.RightToLeftLayout"></xref> property changes.
For more information about handling events, see [Events](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/b6f65241-e0ad-4590-a99f-200ce741bb1f).

Gets or sets the amount by which to increment the current value of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar"></xref> when the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.PerformStep"></xref> method is called.
An integer representing the incremental amount.
The default value is 10.
Gets or sets the style of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar"></xref>.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ProgressBarStyle"></xref> values.
The default value is <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ProgressBarStyle.Blocks"></xref>.
Gets or sets the text displayed on the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar"></xref>.
Although the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar> has a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Text%2A> property, no text is shown on the control.
A <xref href="System.String"></xref> representing the display text.
This event is not relevant for this class.
This event is not relevant for this class.
This event is not relevant to this class.
This event is not relevant to this class.
This event is not relevant to this class.
This event is not relevant to this class.
Gets or sets the current value of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar"></xref>.

The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Value%2A> property must be in the range specified by the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Minimum%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Maximum%2A> properties.
An integer representing the current value.
